data.text: Do You Worry about the Weight of Your Bike Touring Equipment?

How much do you guys worry about the weight of your equipment? Say If you were choosing between two pieces of equipment. One of them is one pound and the other is a pound and a half. If the lighter piece of equipment was twice as expensive, but the only difference was weight. Would you choose to pay twice as much for the lighter piece of equipment? Or would you ride with the extra half pound? For my backpacking equipment. I almost always go for the lighter equipment. This would be for bicycle touring not bike packing. ÔøºÔøº
You will probably use your bike for a loooong time, so I try to watch the weight yes. But then again, I¬¥m using a folding bike so I have to lift it up a lot.
data.author: Martino Wullems

data.text: I basically go with what I have and slowly replace with lighter stuff as time goes on. There are some exceptions for example I opted for a two man tent for just myself. Next thing to replace will be my old sleeping pad (which weighs more than my tent) but that will be maybe a couple of years
data.author: David Cavers

data.text: That‚Äôs the situation I‚Äôm in. Ôøº I replaced my sleeping pad with a lighter one. I like to bring a camp chair and debating on replacing the one I have. Ôøº
data.author: Jr Macintire

data.text: What sleeping pad did you opt for? Mine is an old Nemo(can‚Äôt remember what model) that I used to use for car camping. I love it because it‚Äôs super comfy and quiet. I dislike it because it‚Äôs very heavy and bulky.
data.author: David Cavers

data.text: my last one was an REI Stratus. I ended up going with EXPED ultra 3r. I got the large wide and it‚Äôs still lighter than my other one. I‚Äôm a side sleeper so I need something that doesn‚Äôt put a lot of weight on my hips. This will be the first time I use it on my next trip. But just laying on it feels pretty comfortable. ÔøºÔøºÔøºÔøºÔøºÔøº
data.author: Jr Macintire

data.text: Is it quiet? I‚Äôve tried out a few at the local outdoor store and found many of them to be very noisy.
data.author: David Cavers

data.text: I didn‚Äôt notice any noise. My other one would make a bit of noise. The new one is also self inflating and once you get the hang of it not hard to use. ÔøºÔøºÔøº
data.author: Jr Macintire

data.text: I just keep my total carrying weight ideally at 35 pounds with a max at 40.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: I've come to a kind of zen-like understanding about weight and equipment and how it is carried. For backpacking, I go as light as possible within budget, so I would buy the 1 pounder, because it is on me all the time every step up, down and flat. For bike touring/bikepacking I don't worry as much about the weight because the bike will carry it for at least part of the trip (down and about 50:50 on the flat), but I take into account the terrain: lots of hills (me carrying the weight) then yes go for the 1 pounder, relatively flat then spend money elsewhere. And when sea kayaking, I take heavy stuff, because I'm not really going to carry it myself very far, so the cast iron skillet is coming with me because I like it, unless I have to portage.
data.author: Mike Kroeger

data.text: price, to weight is really a personal choice.....dont go crazy, for any amt, of weight...
data.author: Philip Buckley

data.text: an oft overlooked place to save, big is in shoes....as the leverage rate is one lb, on the foot is equal to five, on the back....
data.author: Philip Buckley

data.text: I use what I have. If my setup is heavier that just means I‚Äôll get stronger! üòÄ
data.author: John Bobstone

data.text: Boy, oh boy, what does it feel like to pack your touring bike? What about that gear-list that seems to grow? How do you get so much stuff into four panniers and a rear day pack? How much weight can those 36 spokes on your rear wheel take? How much weight can your legs take cranking up a 12,000-foot pass in the Colorado Rocky Mountains? How much sweat can you handle dripping off your nose, seeping into your eyes or running down the middle of your back‚Äîas you hammer across Arizona in June? While I pack 80 pounds of gear in Western countries, I haul 100 pounds of gear in remote countries around the world. If you‚Äôre unprepared out in the middle of Timbuktu, you‚Äôre screwed. Preparation equates to 9/10ths of success. In the end, you get to pack your bike to make you happy. Make it light or heavy or in between. In the end, you pedal yourself in those magical moments on adventure highway. FW
data.author: Tom Middaugh

data.text: Just like backpacking, weight is noticeable and you‚Äôll want the lightest gear that fits your budget.
data.author: Brandon G Lampley

data.text: I mean‚Ä¶. The number 1 story you hear is over packing and either quitting or mailing back‚Ä¶ so?
data.author: John Michael

data.text: Go with what makes you happy.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: i think it depends on how many items your doin this too. if it‚Äôs just one item, half pound then i wouldn‚Äôt care. but doin that to half your gear. that‚Äôll add up alotta extra weight quick
data.author: Tdogg Tdogg

data.text: I‚Äôd weigh them again with a modern system and then see which was most useful, packed down the smallest and then worry about a few grammes.
data.author: Matt Kemp

data.text: Fortunately weight is no issue with an ebike anymore. Just buy quality stuff
data.author: Hans Ter Veer

data.text: I always think, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just loose half a pound and call it even!‚Äù
data.author: Rhonda Klann Leduc

data.text: Not much. I carry a few luxuries, theyre heavy but without them the whole thing becomes less enjoyable, so I'm ok with that. After a long day in the saddle, especially when the weather's bad, or the roads busy, a few luxuries can make a lot of difference.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: The biggest differentiator I come across is the quantity of stuff rather than the weight of each individual item.
data.author: Jon Slade

data.text: I mean, we ride for fun and don't have a any speed/distance goals really. So for us I'd definitely not pay double for half a pound less! But I guess if your wallet is big it might be different.
data.author: Charlotte Kramer

data.text: I try real hard to keep cost down , and feel it's an insult to my intelligence to pay more than a thing real worth because of some clever marketing . A good starting point is to start with hiking equipment ( normally carry less weight when hiking ) and see if I can adapt it for touring . The lightest or the cheapest not always the best . Some things I am not prepared to compromise on regardless of it weight or cost . Got mattress or mat and good sleeping bag are one of them .
data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: I‚Äôm unemployed but I would rather go for lighter stuff as it‚Äôs easier to carry even on the bike carry on camping folks
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: I weight 13st in my brithday suit on a good day so I don't worry too much about the weight of the bike. If I want to travel lighter the place to start is around my waistline.
data.author: Alan Myler

data.text: Same here
data.author: Evan Chapple

data.text: Do you need any different kit for bike touring over backpacking? I use the same kit. I did buy a lighter tent (1kg less) but it was actually cheaper!
data.author: Malcolm Frost

data.text: Malcolm same .. 1-man (1kg) + tarp = ¬£60; 2-man (3kg) durable = ¬£160
data.author: Lincs Hcrib

data.text: Nah, the only real differences are the luggage and the fact that if you're on a bike, you'll need to carry some tools and spares to keep it running smoothly. I use the same tent, sleeping bags, mat, stove, pot, first aid kit etc etc that I use for backpacking.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text:
Here is our equipment list light and so far seems to be good quality https://velotouring.fun/kit-list

velotouring.fun
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: If you can carry the weight go for the best product. Weight shouldn't be the end all be all unless it's prohibiting you from doing the activity you want to do.
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: I watched a tour de france domestic rider idling his shirt with water yesterday. He probably had more weight than I take on tour. I'd run with what you have replace with more suitable.
data.author: John Axson

data.text: Good question. I carry a foldable tool pack rather than a multi tool ever since I broke one cutting my thumb. The axle/screw the multi tools are mounted on only take so much torque. What‚Äôs pictured isn‚Äôt a complete representation of what I carry in it because I actually use some of the tools almost daily and left them outside on my bench. Multi tools are better than nothing, but, a foldable pack has the variety and durability I can count on
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: Okay so I tried to answer the question posting a pic of my foldable pack compared to a multi tool, and comment was automatically declined? What is going here, censorship is bizarre

data.text: , yeah, multi tools are better than nothing, but one broke and cut me good, and I prefer to have a variety. Also not pictured is a chain ring bolt tool because many do come loose and won‚Äôt lock down with just an Allen wrench

data.author: Garth Berry

data.text: oh yeah, like I said, I carry a lot less on local rides. What usually happens is a spoke will break and I‚Äôm so close to home that I just wait to put the bike in the stand. If on a long ride far from home I‚Äôll have red and black spoke wrenches with a couple 310mm spokes which I can cut to length and bend into a soft S for a makeshift spoke head , and works on all my friends bikes too
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: What is going on with the erratic censorship here? I posted a picture of the foldable tool pack I normally carry instead of a multi tool, explained why, my comment was automatically declined! I post a picture separately, make another comment asking what‚Äôs going on, those are acceptable? Getting like Facebook personnel with bizarre and debased censorship, I didn‚Äôt break any rules
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: Very open ended question. Generally speaking with the lighter gear. A 50% increase in weight is not worth it if all things are equal. Although the thickness of your bags (fork, panniers). Should probably not be ultra sill thin. That‚Äôs where I would change my answer, tough bags for dealing with curbs, bike racks and all the other stuff you lean it up against. I‚Äôve been burned in the past with too light of bags.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: I think a good compromise between price and packsize is my priority. I dont mind the weight as long as everything I need fits in my 2 panniers. I hate bulky
data.author: Patricia Larsson

data.text: It all depends on you and your level of comfort you want to keep. I have done a few short runs of about 100 miles each way for some overnights but nothing serious yet, I am still new. I bring a lot of stuff which includes a chair that collapses into a bag and weighs about a pound, my tent is about 4 pounds but also sometimes just use a hammock, i also have a table which is just a few ounces and designed for mountain climbing along with all the other normal gear, tool kit, first aid, fod and clothes.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: what chair have you got ?

data.text: Depends how often you realistically think you will use it and how long you‚Äôd be riding. The initial investment of light gear is substantial. But once you‚Äôve paid for it, you‚Äôll have it for a long time.
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: Can I phone a friend on that question....?
data.author: Donald Canard

data.text: I‚Äôd rather be comfortable then miserable over saving a couple pounds!
data.author: Jim M. Leone

data.text: I minimize weight because I'm a very small person who cycles solo and camps. But it also matters a lot where those 8oz are being added with the heavier gear. Where's the value being added (or is there any)? Better, more comfortable sleep? More protection from the weather? Or just lowered $$? Etc.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: Low weight is more crucial in backpacking than bicycle touring.
data.author: Greg Morath

data.text: Eight ounces is a lot. Every time you pack that object you will ponder ditching it. The more I rode, the less stuff I carried--or needed. Rather than a tent and sleeping, I use a gortex bivvie bag and a synthetic blanket. I even broke a whetstone in half, saved two ounces.
data.author: Kenneth Paul

data.text: less is more

data.text: This is the beauty of an E bike. You can forget weight

data.text: I admit I dont understand E Bikes...I don't want a assist. I realize its me but I take all the pride in doing it with my own two legs.
data.author: David Campbell

data.text: Yes I would‚Äôve said that up until a couple of years ago but then I am 72
data.author: Robbie Benstead

data.text: Now that makes sense.
data.author: David Campbell

data.text: well it keeps me out there anyway with still some exercise because I‚Äôve only got 250 W limited to 15.5 mph, and won‚Äôt work if you don‚Äôt pedalÔøºÔøº
data.author: Robbie Benstead

data.text: I'm 60 and going strong but there will come a day I might very well change my mind about them.
data.author: David Campbell

data.text: My first tour, with lots of mountain passes and steep climbs, I did not worry about weight. When in doubt I took that other vest, because you never know. I even carried two inner tubes, and one outer tube. I learned, I am reducing weight whenever I can. If I cannot afford a lightweight version, I think about going completely without. I might replace the outer tube with a sturdy sewing kit. I got lightweight inner tubes. I am still undecided about both the tarp - I made one which is 2*2 meters, it might be too small - and the sleeping bag. The only way to lose one pound would be to get a down-filled sleeping bag, and I worry about the geese. Here I guess I'll stick with the heavy one I got.
data.author: Michaela Eff

data.text: What usually happens if I'm on a long/difficult tour is that I'll start ditching things or mailing them home. Riding up a mountain or two makes one acutely aware of every tiny uneccessary item! By the end I'm dialed in, just the essentials. If it's a short and/or easy tour, I worry less about weight. My primary concerns are whether the bike and my body are in good shape.
data.author: Scott Black

data.text: I have a Luci solar inflatable light, brilliant!!
data.author: Malcolm Frost

data.text: I don‚Äôt care about the weight as I am on a tricycle with a dog and trailer, your just a bit slower but you can carry more, I say comfort and been ready for anything is better than weight,
data.author: Donald Jones
